Discretionary access control (DAC) allows users to control access to resources based on their own discretion. This method is commonly used in operating systems that use a trusted computing base (TCB) model, where users have the ability to assign permissions to resources.

Mandatory access control (MAC) is a method of access control that is enforced by the system and cannot be overridden by the user. This method is commonly used in military and government environments, where security is of the utmost importance.

Role-based access control (RBAC) is a method of access control that assigns permissions to users based on their role within an organization. This method is commonly used in large enterprises, where there may be many different types of users with varying levels of access to resources.
